7 days

Copper Canyon: 7 Days

Mexico's Grand Canyon by Train

Copper Canyon (Barrancas del Cobre) is actually a series of six interconnected canyons—larger and deeper than the Grand Canyon. The legendary El Chepe train traverses this spectacular landscape, passing through 86 tunnels and over 37 bridges. Combined with hiking, Tarahumara indigenous culture, and authentic Northern Mexican hospitality, this is one of Mexico's greatest adventures.

Trip Highlights

  • Ride the El Chepe scenic railway through 37 bridges and 86 tunnels
  • Gaze into canyons deeper than the Grand Canyon
  • Meet the Tarahumara (Rarámuri) people and learn their traditions
  • Hike to waterfalls, canyon rims, and remote villages
  • Experience authentic Northern Mexico culture and cuisine
  • Stay in cliff-edge lodges with dramatic views
Duration
7 days
Best Time
October-November (fall colors), March-April (spring). Avoid summer (rainy, obscured views) and deep winter (cold at altitude).
Budget (Mid-Range)
$1,500-2,500 USD

Day-by-Day Itinerary

1

Arrive Los Mochis or El Fuerte

Begin your journey in Sinaloa state, gateway to the canyons.

Today's Activities:
2

El Chepe Train to Cerocahui

Begin the spectacular railway journey into the canyons.

Today's Activities:
3

Urique Canyon - Mexico's Deepest

Full day exploring the deepest of the Copper Canyon system.

Today's Activities:
4

Train to Divisadero - The Great Views

Continue by train to the most dramatic viewpoints of the canyon system.

Today's Activities:
5

Train to Creel - Mountain Town

Continue to the Sierra Tarahumara's main town.

Today's Activities:
6

Creel Excursions - Lakes & Waterfalls

Full day exploring the spectacular surroundings of Creel.

Today's Activities:
7

Train to Chihuahua - Journey's End

Complete the El Chepe journey descending to Chihuahua city.

Today's Activities:

Practical Information

Getting There

Fly into Los Mochis (LMM) or Chihuahua (CUU) from Mexico City, Guadalajara, or other hubs. The route can be done either direction. West-to-east (Los Mochis to Chihuahua) means climbing into the canyons; east-to-west descends.
